issue.title: Hide uncompression progress
issue.body:
Hi @megastep 

First of all, thanks for makeself. It really helps me almost everyday.
Just one little thing annoys me and would like to know if it's possible to hide it:
```
./myapp
Verifying archive integrity... 100% All good.
Uncompressing My awesome command line tool    100%

Usage: myapp [opts]
```

Is it possible to hide the first two lines from the output? These two:
```
Verifying archive integrity... 100% All good.
Uncompressing My awesome command line tool    100%
```

What i'd like to eventually see is just this:
```
./myapp
Usage: myapp [opts]
```

Help appreciated and thanks again

comment.body: Feel free to make PR if you'd like as long as you keep that behavior opt-in.

issue.title: Hide uncompression progress
issue.body:
Hi @megastep 

First of all, thanks for makeself. It really helps me almost everyday.
Just one little thing annoys me and would like to know if it's possible to hide it:
```
./myapp
Verifying archive integrity... 100% All good.
Uncompressing My awesome command line tool    100%

Usage: myapp [opts]
```

Is it possible to hide the first two lines from the output? These two:
```
Verifying archive integrity... 100% All good.
Uncompressing My awesome command line tool    100%
```

What i'd like to eventually see is just this:
```
./myapp
Usage: myapp [opts]
```

Help appreciated and thanks again

comment.body: Hi, yes it is possible to hide the output by providing the `--quiet` argument on the command line. I realize this is not exactly what you are asking for, however Makeself is not really meant to be used to start normal commands, but rather extract and install them.

commits.message:
fix #282 redux: ESXi workaround: 'tr' -> 'sed' (#286)

ESXi v6.5 ships without 'tr'. Within 'makeself-header.sh', replace every
instance of

    tr -d " "

with

    sed "s/ //g"

pull_request.title: fix #282 redux: ESXi workaround: 'tr' -> 'sed'

ESXi v6.5 ships without 'tr'. Within 'makeself-header.sh', replace every instance of

    tr -d " "

with

    sed "s/ //g"

issue.title: fix #282 redux: ESXi workaround: 'tr' -> 'sed'

ESXi v6.5 ships without 'tr'. Within 'makeself-header.sh', replace every instance of

comment.body: Yeah these NetBSD issues are completely unrelated and I only noticed them yesterday. I can merge this now.

issue.title: NetBSD checksum verification failing
issue.body:
Just noticed this as I implemented NetBSD CI for the repository, it appears that the MD5 checksums are failing on that platform, and thus archives can not be extracted.

Need to investigate and find a fix.

issue.title: [QUESTION] How to extract to a target dir? --target dir doesn't work the way I hoped.
issue.body:
The file of the link below contains a parent directory with the name of the archive. If I just double click the file and select "Execute", the parent directory is properly extracted with everything in it. But if I write ./archivename.sh --target [target path] in terminal, then only the contents of the parent directory is extracted, but not the parent directory itself. That particular file is a mod for American Truck Simulator and it has to have a parent directory. It will probably work without it but having the parent directory makes it easier to find the mod and know what it is for.
So, how do I extract the contents of the sh file along with the parent directory it contains?

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1-1kbCm8g9eM7WKjGzrwz9T4E5Q3o0fhJ/view?usp=sharing

comment.body:
This is actually the intended behavior. The `--target` option is typically used explicitly when you want to keep the contents of the file to a specific directory, otherwise the archive is extracted to a temporary location and the embedded script is in charge of dealing with the actual installation (i.e. copy the files to the right place, etc).

So typically the most common use case would be to have the script handle those details for you...

commits.message: Use readlink to help on NetBSD
Added NetBSD testing; update checkout action for lint
Added OpenBSD tests
Updated versions of VM addons

issue.title: ESXi compatibility
issue.body:
I recently had the pleasure of porting a tool to run on ESXi and ran into some incompatibilities with Makeself, some of which may be intractable. I'd like your input on this before submitting a PR.  The ESXi shell is a heavily stripped `busybox` implementation, lacking some typically available features.

* ESXi shell lacks `tr` ([example usage](https://github.com/megastep/makeself/blob/master/makeself-header.sh#L203)). I had to use `sed -e 's/ //g'` instead.
* The busybox `df` used in ESXi [lacks the -P flag](https://github.com/megastep/makeself/blob/master/makeself-header.sh#L95). I recognize this is used to ensure a consistent columnar structure, so struggle with the decision to patch it out permanently. Any thoughts?

issue.title: ESXi compatibility
issue.body:
I recently had the pleasure of porting a tool to run on ESXi and ran into some incompatibilities with Makeself, some of which may be intractable. I'd like your input on this before submitting a PR.  The ESXi shell is a heavily stripped `busybox` implementation, lacking some typically available features.

* ESXi shell lacks `tr` ([example usage](https://github.com/megastep/makeself/blob/master/makeself-header.sh#L203)). I had to use `sed -e 's/ //g'` instead.
* The busybox `df` used in ESXi [lacks the -P flag](https://github.com/megastep/makeself/blob/master/makeself-header.sh#L95). I recognize this is used to ensure a consistent columnar structure, so struggle with the decision to patch it out permanently. Any thoughts?

comment.body: OK, merged your PR! Hope this fixes this without breaking anything else. :)

commits.message:
fix 282: 'df -kP' -> 'df -k' (#283)

Because VMware ESXi version 6.5 ships 'df' as a (very) non-compliant python
script that (surprise) doesn't support your fancy POSIX output format.

Further reading:

* https://git.busybox.net/busybox/tree/coreutils/df.c
* https://github.com/landley/toybox/blob/master/toys/posix/df.c
* https://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/utilities/df.html

pull_request.title: fix 282: 'df -kP' -> 'df -k'
pull_request.body:
Because VMware ESXi version 6.5 ships 'df' as a (very) non-compliant python script that (surprise) doesn't support your fancy POSIX output format.

Further reading:

* https://git.busybox.net/busybox/tree/coreutils/df.c
* https://github.com/landley/toybox/blob/master/toys/posix/df.c
* https://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/utilities/df.html

repo.name: makeself
repo.description: A self-extracting archiving tool for Unix systems, in 100% shell script.

repo.name: makeself
repo.description: A self-extracting archiving tool for Unix systems, in 100% shell script.

commits.message: Enable iPad in example app.
Fix layouts of sections, add canonical URLs
Provide reference to card button in closure
Use parent view size as a basis to compute banner width if available.
Properly spell positionView()
Invoke delegate methods at more appropriate times
Made more queue methods public.

Added Swift Package Manager support + Objective-C compatibility (#1)

* Added Swift Package Manager support.
* Make default queue accessible from Objective-C
* Export removeAll() to Objective-C.
* Expose most of the API to Objective-C
* Better handling of Objective-C enums
* Made all delegate methods optional.
Made all delegate methods optional.

issue.title: Added Swift Package Manager support
issue.body:
Hi,

I've added a simple Package.swift to allow this package to be imported in Xcode via the standard Swift Package Manager, as CocoaPods is becoming increasingly deprecated.

Also made a couple of small changes to make the queue more usable from Objective-C.

comment.body: Added more Objective-C exports as I thought that was already the case. The project is now largely usable from Objective-C code.

commits.message: Better handling of Objective-C enums
Expose most of the API to Objective-C

pull_request.title: Added Swift Package Manager support
pull_request.body:
Hi,

I've added a simple Package.swift to allow this package to be imported in Xcode via the standard Swift Package Manager, as CocoaPods is becoming increasingly deprecated.

Also made a couple of small changes to make the queue more usable from Objective-C.
